We show that the category of Hilbert spaces and linear operators has an initial object, which is unique up to canonical isomorphism. This provides a foundation for quantum theory that is purely categorical and is independent of any analytical structure. The result is a natural part of any axiomatization of quantum theory.

The origin of parasitism is one of the most fundamental questions in biology. Here, we show that the Myxozoa, a group of microscopic parasites, are cnidarians, which are responsible for the stinging of jellyfish and corals. This finding has profound implications for the origin of parasitism and the evolution of the body plan in animals.

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is a common strategy used by pathogens to survive and propagate in their host. In this study, we describe a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. Our findings have implications for the development of antiviral strategies against SARS-CoV-2 and other viruses. (Show more)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of the proton channel. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric channel. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on the channel: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits the channel will further our understanding of the channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for the channel. We show that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially in the future, even if the mean yield remains unchanged. This increase in variability will be especially large in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries, where it will increase the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year. Our results highlight the need for investments in breeding for heat tolerance, which is the most important adaptation to climate change in maize.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of quantifying diet composition at the species level. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species of wild and domestic LMH in semiarid African savanna. We found that, despite being similar in body size and proportional grass consumption, these species differed in diet composition, and that dietary overlap was greatest between species that were dissimilar in these traits. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our findings have implications for the management of LMH populations and the conservation of biodiversity in African savanna. (Show more)

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Many businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand at the time of the survey. Many businesses plan to apply for loans under the CARES Act, but many anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is far less than expected, mostly accumulating in the convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres. However, the fate of the missing plastic debris is still unknown. This is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.
The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in science. We determined the age of the solar system and the age of the solar system’s building blocks.

We have reconstructed the evolution of the global fishing fleet and its fishing effort, disaggregating the data into three sectors: artisanal (unpowered/powered) and industrial. We show that the global fishing fleet doubled between 1950 and 2015, driven by the expansion of the motorized fleet, particularly, of the powered-artisanal fleet. We also show that the effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. We conclude that the global fleet is unsustainable and that the effective management of fisheries is needed to ensure the long-term sustainability of the global fishing fleet.

The ability to increase the amount of energy available to the mother is a key factor in the evolution of all forms of care. Here, we show that the increase in energy available to the mother is a key factor in the evolution of all forms of care. We show that the increase in energy available to the mother is a key factor in the evolution of all forms of care.

In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is well tolerated in patients with epilepsy, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This study provides a proof of concept for the use of VX-765 in a mouse model of multiple system atrophy, a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder, and opens the door for further studies in patients.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the interface between the circulatory system and the tissues of the body. It is the primary regulator of vascular function and is the target of many diseases. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It is constantly receiving information from the outside world and must integrate this information to control vascular function. This paper describes the nature of the communication system that the endothelium uses to integrate information and control vascular function.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. We describe the design and operation of the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of data on COVID-19 activity, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making. The COVIDcast API is available at https://covidcast.org.

The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel’s pore and is the site of ion conduction. In this work, we show that the selectivity filter can be structurally collapsed by the closing of the channel’s activation gate. This structural collapse of the selectivity filter is a key step in the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is influenced by the host and the environment. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is still being elucidated, and the potential for natural products to regulate the microbiome is an emerging field of research. This study demonstrates that anaerobic fungi, which are members of the gut microbiome, synthesize natural products. These natural products could be used to modulate the microbiome and, thus, influence health.

Anxiety is a common feature of many psychiatric disorders, and the brain energy metabolism in the nucleus accumbens (NAc) is known to be altered in anxiety. However, the role of mitochondrial function in the NAc in the context of social behavior has not been investigated. Here we show that high-anxious rats are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat and that this is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the NAc. We further demonstrate that the low probability to become dominant in high-anxious animals is mediated by the NAc and that this is associated with reduced mitochondrial function. Our findings suggest that mitochondrial function in the NAc is crucial for social hierarchy establishment and point to mitochondrial function in the NAc as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This study provides a link between anxiety and mitochondrial function in the brain and may have implications for the treatment of anxiety disorders. (PsycINFO Database Record

The design of mechanical structures with desired behaviors is of great importance for the development of mechanical devices. However, the use of a single material phase and the design of a specific structure are often insufficient to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a synthesis method of composite structures with multiple material phases and demonstrate that the structures can be used to design structures with arbitrary and extreme responses. The structures are digitally synthesized through a free-form inverse design approach, which can be extended to the design of structures with complex behaviors. The structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication and are physically and accurately realized in experiments. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work provides a new paradigm for the design of mechanical structures with desired behaviors. It is expected to have a significant impact on the development of mechanical devices.

The hemoglobin system is a key regulator of the timing of development and differentiation in mammals. In this study, we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is expressed in the human erythroid system and that it can reverse the adult hemoglobin expression pattern toward a more fetal-like phenotype. This is achieved by reduced expression of the alpha-globin gene, which is the major contributor to adult hemoglobin, and increased expression of the gamma-globin gene, which is the major contributor to fetal hemoglobin. This study provides a mechanism for chronoregulation of hemoglobin expression in humans.

Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway confers resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis that is regulated by iron-dependent peroxidation of phospholipids. This resistance is mediated by the activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1/monounsaturated fatty acids/stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1-dependent lipogenesis, which in turn promotes the survival of cancer cells. Thus, the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway may be a promising target for the treatment of cancer, and the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction may be a promising strategy for the treatment of cancer. Hypertension is the most common cause of heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of the treatment of heart failure. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the use of LCCBs is associated with the development of heart failure. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) and promote vascular remodeling. Our findings suggest that the use of LCCBs should be limited in patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling. This study provides a mechanism of LCCBs action and may help to improve the safety of LCCBs. It also provides a new target for the treatment of hypertension and heart failure. (Show more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP was not successful in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. Instead, the policy halted the creation of early-seral ecosystems, which are important for early-seral bird populations. Our findings underscore the need to continue to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and to ensure that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. In this study, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This study provides a proof of concept for the rational design of new antibiotics. The approach presented here can be extended to other classes of antibiotics and can be used to design new drugs for the treatment of other diseases. This approach can be used to design new drugs for the treatment of other diseases.

We introduce a new deep convolutional neural network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The architecture is based on a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters than popular existing architectures, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data, and is easier to train and apply in practice.

The evolution of the Lake Malawi cichlid fish species flock is a classic example of the effects of environmental change on biological adaptation. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind, 1.3-My record of hydroclimate variability from Lake Malawi, East Africa. The record shows that the lake underwent large-scale changes in water level, which had a profound influence on the evolution of the cichlid fish species flock. The lake underwent a major shift in hydroclimate at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition, which coincided with a change in the rate of evolution of the cichlid fish species flock.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. However, the effects of these devices on sleep and circadian rhythms are not well understood. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device suppresses melatonin, reduces sleepiness, and phase-delays the circadian clock, all of which may have important implications for performance, health, and safety. These results have implications for the design of electronic devices and the development of sleep and circadian health guidelines. (PsycINFO Database Record

The Younger Dryas cooling is a key event in the Earth’s history, but the cause of the cooling is still debated. One of the proposed causes is the impact of a bolide. We show that the osmium isotopic composition of the Younger Dryas sediments is consistent with the osmium isotopic composition of osmium in the impactor.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is still unclear. Here, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 in adult mice leads to a spectrum of autoimmunity, which is not only more severe than congenital deficiency but also can be reversed by Treg cells. This indicates that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity, and that its function in the immune system is not limited to the regulation of T cell activation.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification, and a dataset of 154 genomes or transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls. Our analyses resolved previously controversial beetle relationships, dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. Moreover, plant cell wall-degrading enzymes obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles—remarkably, both major independent origins of specialized herbivory in beetles coincide with the first appearances of these genes. We propose that these genes enabled efficient digestion of plant tissues, including lignocellulose in cell walls, facilitating the evolution of uniquely specialized plant-feeding habits, such as leaf mining and stem and wood boring.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 variants. (Show more)

We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE). We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor for AD is the APOE ε4 allele. APOE is a major plasma lipoprotein and is also expressed by astrocytes, a major cell type in the central nervous system. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. We also found that APOE alleles affect the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses in the brain, which may contribute to the increased vulnerability of APOE4 to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis is consistent with the observation that APOE4 is associated with increased risk of stroke.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is thought to have formed by the crystallization of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We show that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is much more likely than that of the hcp phase, which is the stable phase of iron at the inner core conditions. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which solves the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also provides a clue to understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our findings have implications for the origin of the inner core and the evolution of the core–mantle boundary. They also provide a new perspective for the study of the nucleation of other materials. Marijuana is a drug that is widely used, but its effects on the brain are not well understood. Here, we show that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate (a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine [DA]) is reduced in marijuana abusers, who are more likely to be addicted to marijuana. This reduced reactivity might contribute to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the brain’s processing of it is a central focus of neuroscience. However, the brain’s language system is not a single structure or process, but rather a set of interacting mechanisms. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks can predict the brain’s responses to sentences in the human language system with similar accuracy to human observers. These results provide computational support for the existence of multiple interacting language mechanisms in the brain, and suggest that predictive processing may be a fundamental mechanism of higher-level cognition.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many areas of science and engineering. However, it is still an open question whether DL can be made stable, i.e., compute the same solution with the same accuracy regardless of the initialization. We show that this is not the case, and that there are problems where the existence of stable DL methods is ruled out by the theory of numerical linear algebra. This theory, in turn, can be used to design fast and stable DL methods.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. It is also a scientific scandal. The pandemic’s origin is a matter of scientific dispute, but the scientific community’s response to the pandemic has been to focus on the wrong question. Instead of asking why people are not wearing masks, scientists should be asking why they are not dying of COVID-19. The answer to that question is not that people are unable to understand exponential growth. It is that they are unable to understand the scientific method.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries, and the cause of the disease has been debated for even longer. In this study, we sequenced the genome of a patient from Mexico who had a reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon. We found that the genome of this patient is very similar to that of the leprosy bacillus, suggesting that the reactional state is caused by a leprosy bacillus. This study also provides evidence that the leprosy bacillus has been present in humans for a long time, and that the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved despite their ancient separation. This study provides a better understanding of the evolution of the leprosy bacillus and may lead to the discovery of a new leprosy pathogen. (PsycINFO Database Record

The dynamics of entanglement and entropy in isolated quantum systems is a central topic of current research. However, an exact computation of the entanglement dynamics was available so far only for noninteracting systems, whereas it was deemed unfeasible for interacting ones. Here, we show that the standard quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics, complemented with integrability-based knowledge of the steady state and its excitations, leads to a complete understanding of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit. We thoroughly check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain.

The development of a safe and effective vaccine against SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, is a critical need to combat the pandemic. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate, COVI-VAC, that is based on a temperature-sensitive live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 strain. This vaccine candidate is highly attenuated, has a small genome, and is easy to manufacture. In addition, it can be delivered by nasal administration, which is a route that is well tolerated and easy to administer. These properties make COVI-VAC a promising vaccine candidate for use in mass vaccination programs.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is still debated, with the most common assumption being that rats were the main vectors. Here, we show that human ectoparasites, such as fleas or lice, were the primary vectors of plague during the Second Pandemic. This is a major change in the understanding of the history of plague, which will have important implications for the control of the disease.

The evolution of brain size has been used as a proxy for the evolution of cognitive ability. However, this approach is biased by the fact that brains of different sizes have different numbers of neurons, which are the basic units of information processing. Here, we show that the evolution of brain size in amniotes is characterized by two major shifts in neuron–brain scaling, resulting in a 20-fold increase in neuron numbers in birds and mammals relative to reptiles. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The role of TRAP1 in cancer has been controversial. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This study provides a mechanistic explanation for the role of TRAP1 in cancer and may have implications for the design of new therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in severing actin filaments. However, the mechanism by which it does so is not known. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to show that ADF binds to actin filaments and, upon local curvature, to the filament ends. We also show that the binding of ADF to the filament ends, which is required for severing, is enhanced by a mechanical torque. We propose that this mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings have implications for our understanding of severing in general and for the design of new drugs that target severing. They also have implications for our understanding of the role of actin in the formation of stress fibers and lamellipodia.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in the food supply, and it is thought to be a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose. This study shows that fructose ingestion results in greater brain activation in regions involved in attention and reward processing, and it promotes greater hunger and desire for food and a greater willingness to give up long-term monetary rewards to obtain immediate high-calorie foods. These findings suggest that fructose may be a stronger feeding stimulus than glucose. The results have implications for the development of obesity and for the design of strategies to promote weight loss. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island and show that the settlement history of Madagascar is complex. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals, but we also find that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, with a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterns. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia. In addition, we show that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a new perspective on the settlement history of Madagascar and the origin of the Malagasy people. It also provides a new tool to study the human history of other islands in the Indian Ocean. This work is important for understanding the origin of the Malagasy people and the origin of the island itself.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This constitutes experimental evidence for massive-scale contagion via social networks. In contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These findings have implications for the design of social media platforms, the spread of misinformation, and the design of interventions to reduce the spread of negative emotions. They also suggest that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These findings have implications for the design of social media platforms, the spread of misinformation, and the design of interventions to reduce the spread of negative emotions.

The presence of RNA modifications in coding regions of messenger RNAs (mRNAs) has been shown to impact protein synthesis. However, the impact of modifications in the coding regions of mRNAs on translation is not well understood. Here, we show that the presence of a modification in the mRNA can impact the rate of translation. We show that the presence of a modification in the mRNA can impact the rate of translation. We also show that the presence of a modification in the mRNA can impact the rate of translation.

We show that feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, more social and economic engagement, and less loneliness. These associations are robust to the inclusion of a range of potential confounders, and they are also evident over a 4-y period. These findings suggest that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may be a key factor in promoting healthy aging and sustaining optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms.

The common cold is the most common disease worldwide, and rhinovirus is the main cause of the common cold. The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication has been studied for more than 50 y, but the mechanism of temperature dependence is not understood. Here, we show that mouse-adapted rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperature of the nasal cavity than at the core body temperature, and that this temperature dependence is dependent on the antiviral defense response of infected cells. These findings provide insight into the mechanism of temperature dependence of rhinovirus and may have implications for the development of antiviral therapies for the common cold. (PsycINFO Database Record

The type IV pili of bacteria are used for a variety of functions, including twitching motility and surface attachment. Here we show that the pili are also used as a sensor for the detection of surfaces. This is the first demonstration of a mechanochemical model for the sensing of surfaces by a bacterial cell.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades, and the use of insecticides in particular is associated with a substantial risk to aquatic biodiversity. However, the extent of the risk is not well understood because of a lack of comprehensive quantitative analysis. We provide a global metaanalysis of the occurrence of pesticides in surface water and the risk of exceeding the legally accepted regulatory threshold levels. Our results show that the risk of exceeding the threshold is high, especially for newer-generation insecticides. These results highlight the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions. This information is critical for the development of effective strategies to mitigate the risk of pesticide contamination to aquatic ecosystems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on the human population, and the animal population is no exception. In this study, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer, which is a significant finding because of the potential for the virus to persist in the wild animal population. This study also highlights the importance of a “One Health” approach to understand the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This study has implications for the long-term persistence of the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic. (Show more)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the history of the development of hydropower and the proliferation of large dams in the developing world. It also examines the problems that are being repeated in the Mekong River Basin, the Amazon River Basin, and the Congo River Basin. The paper proposes innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources. The paper is intended for a general audience.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder that is characterized by chronic inflammation. However, the origin of this inflammation is still unclear. In this study, we show that soluble and oligomeric amyloid-β (Aβ) are the main toxic species that trigger an inflammatory response in neurons, which precedes the formation of Aβ plaques and tau tangles. This neuron-specific inflammatory response may be a significant contributor to the AD pathogenesis, since it is present in the human brain even before the formation of Aβ plaques. Thus, we propose that the Aβ-burdened neuron may be a primary target for therapeutic intervention.

The earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens is of great importance for the study of the evolution of animal husbandry and the spread of agriculture. However, the earliest known evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is controversial. We present a detailed faunal analysis of the site of Maresha, Israel, and show that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is to be found in the Southern Levant, some 100 y before the earliest evidence from Europe.

The folding of proteins is a major unsolved problem in biology. We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of proteins at the molecular level. We have used this method to study the folding of maltose binding protein, a protein of 370 residues that is known to fold through distinct intermediates. We have found that the folding of the protein is much more complex than previously thought.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates, which are abundant in response to stress, have been shown to function as precursors to RNA caps. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme RppH, which is inactivated by stress, preferentially removes the cap of dinucleoside tetraphosphate, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in the specificity of the enzyme. This shift in substrate specificity, coupled with the unconventional manner in which capped substrates bind to the active site of the enzyme, positions the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, for hydrolytic attack, generating triphosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. This study provides a deeper understanding of the mechanisms by which cells respond to stress and may have implications for the reprogramming of gene expression during stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with a high risk of mortality. Although there are several therapeutic strategies to treat sepsis, there is no specific strategy to restore immune function after sepsis. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression during sepsis. We demonstrated that citrulline administration was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides a strategy to treat sepsis and other conditions in which arginine and citrulline levels are low. This strategy could be used to treat cancer, which is associated with low arginine and citrulline levels. In addition, this strategy could be used to treat other conditions in which arginine and citrulline levels are low, such as diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and neurodegenerative diseases.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers. Our analysis highlights the importance of the global biomass of humans and the need for a more complete census of the biomass of the biosphere. This work is a step toward a better understanding of the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem.

We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) that is continuous in contrast to all known models of SOC. We show that our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is widely used in electronics, optics, and photonics. However, it is brittle and has a low fracture strain, which limits its applications. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, solely under mechanical strain without phonon instability, so that its electronic bandgap fully vanishes. This work offers opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. It also provides a new route to the discovery of new phases of diamond. This work is expected to advance the development of diamond-based devices and applications. It is expected to be of interest to the general scientific community and the diamond industry.

The role of plant immune peptides in the defense of plants against pathogens is well established. However, the role of immune peptides in the defense of plants against other stresses, such as fungal pathogens, is less clear. Here, we show that a structurally unique immune peptide, NCR044, from Medicago truncatula, exhibits potent fungicidal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. The mode of action of this peptide is unique and involves the disruption of the fungal cell wall, followed by the accumulation of the peptide in the nucleoli of the fungal germlings. This work provides a better understanding of the role of immune peptides in the defense of plants against fungal pathogens. It also paves the way for the development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This could be a useful tool for the management of plant fungal diseases.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes, and it is likely that the life history of sperm is intimately linked to the female reproductive tract. Here, we show that the life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome is profoundly affected by the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm, and that these contributions are critical for supporting sperm viability during the prolonged period between mating and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–female reproductive tract interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the surface of platelets. We show that force can be used to switch the conformation of VWF, providing a mechanism for the activation of VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism is important for understanding the pathophysiology of von Willebrand disease, a common disorder of blood clotting.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the role of viruses in human health has only recently been explored. This study is a comprehensive analysis of the human virome, and the results are a resource for future studies. The results are also a resource for the study of the microbiome–disease relationship, as many of the viruses found in this study are known to be associated with disease.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the Earth’s climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is mainly due to the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to measure the aerosol and cloud properties simultaneously. The HSRL is able to measure the aerosol and cloud properties with high-resolution and high-precision. We use the HSRL to investigate the ACI over Beijing. The results show that the aerosol loading has no discernible effect on the liquid water path, but it does affect the cloud droplet number concentration and effective radius. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations obtained from the HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This study is expected to provide a new way to study ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a subject of intense debate for more than a century. The current consensus is that Earth’s surface temperature has decreased over geological time, but the magnitude of the change and the mechanism by which it occurred have been the subject of much speculation. Here, we present a method for determining the temperature of Earth’s surface in the past based on the thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean to the present ∼15 °C.

Ion channels are the main ion-conducting proteins in cells and are also the targets of drugs. Ion channels are activated by opening their pore gates and inactivated by closing their pore gates. The pore gates are often coupled to each other, and the inactivation gates are often coupled to each other. In this study, we found that the K+ channel BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent, and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This study provides a new perspective on the relationship between the activation and inactivation gates and the underlying mechanisms of K+ channel inactivation. It also provides a new approach to the design of K+ channel blockers. (Show more)

Malaria parasite invasion of the red blood cell (RBC) is a critical step in the disease pathogenesis, and the identification of the host cell receptors and parasite adhesins is a major focus of research. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the RBC, which may be a critical step in the invasion process. This finding has implications for our understanding of the invasion process and may suggest that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate entry. This is a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This is a major advance in our understanding of the invasion process. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum devices, and energy storage. However, it is brittle and difficult to process. Here, we show that diamond can be demetallized, and its bandgap can be reduced to zero, by applying strain. This opens up opportunities for tailoring the properties of diamond for applications in electronics, photonics, and energy storage.

The impact of ambient humidity on the severity of influenza virus infection is still controversial. In this study, we show that housing mice in low humidity increases the severity of influenza virus infection. We found that low humidity impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the role of ambient humidity in the severity of influenza virus infection and may help to develop strategies to mitigate the impact of influenza virus outbreaks. (Show more)

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures in a left-corner parser, but the neurophysiological basis of this process is unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words are merged into phrases. This pattern of activity is consistent with a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. More superficial models of language, based solely on sequential transition probability over lexical and syntactic categories, only captured activity in the posterior middle temporal gyrus. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental property of the language system that is shared by humans and other animals.

Wnt signaling is a major pathway in development, and its regulation is critical for the proper functioning of the body. Axin is one of the two scaffolds in this pathway, and its function is to convert the extracellular signal to the degradation of β-catenin, which is then able to enter the nucleus and activate specific genes. We show that the two forms of Axin are similar at the protein level, but differ in their regulation on the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This difference in regulation may be used to control the function of the two forms of Axin in different tissues.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that controls feeding. Here we show that stimulation of LH neurons that project to the lateral hypothalamic area causes animals to eat vigorously. We also show that this system is involved in the regulation of food intake, and that it is a critical downstream circuit element for the regulation of eating.

The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria is a key component of sustainable agriculture. Here, we describe the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis, in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of rhizopine as a synthetic signal for the control of the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis. This work is a significant step toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species.

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

We show that the spider’s web, which is used to construct the spider’s shelter, is also used to detect sound. The spider can hear the sound of its prey moving through the air, and it can localize the sound source.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil fuels and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

COVID-19 is a global pandemic that has killed over 500,000 people in the United States alone. The lack of a vaccine has been a major obstacle to containing the pandemic. Here we report the design and characterization of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD protein that can be expressed in large quantities in bacteria and that can be used to generate antibodies that bind to the RBD of the virus. These antibodies can be used to neutralize the virus in cell culture and in animal models. The RBD protein can be used to generate a virus-like particle that can protect hamsters from the virus. These results suggest that the RBD protein can be used to develop a vaccine that can be used to contain the pandemic.

We show that the zebrafish homolog of anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) and the homolog of the ALK ligand (ALK-ligand) are required for the development of iridophores, a pigment cell type derived from the neural crest. Our results provide in vivo evidence of (i) activation of ALK/ALK ligand receptors by ALKALs and (ii) an involvement of these ligand–receptor complexes in neural crest development.

The emergence of plague, the most devastating infectious disease in human history, is a mystery that has fascinated scientists for centuries. The study of ancient pathogens has provided a unique window into the past, allowing us to understand the origins of this disease and its impact on human history. In this study, we present a comprehensive analysis of the evolution of plague during the Neolithic and Bronze Ages, providing insights into the spread and adaptation of the pathogen during this critical period of development. Our results suggest that plague may have originated in Eurasia and spread to other regions of the world, with a rapid and widespread dispersal across continents. This study provides a valuable resource for further research on the history and evolution of plague, and its impact on human history. (Show more)

This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted men’s and women’s support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The fate of soil organic carbon (SOC) in agricultural systems is a critical question for the future of agriculture and the environment. We show that soil health management practices can increase SOC storage in the subsoil, but the magnitude of these effects is limited by the amount of SOC already stored in the topsoil. These results highlight the importance of maintaining SOC in the topsoil, where it is most vulnerable to the effects of intensive agriculture, and the need for agricultural systems to be designed to maintain SOC in the long term.

The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We used expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify host, viral, and environmental risk factors contributing to zoonotic virus spillover and spread in humans. We then developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates a risk score for wildlife-origin viruses, creating a comparative risk assessment of viruses with uncharacterized zoonotic spillover potential alongside those already known to be zoonotic. Using data from virus discovery and surveillance efforts, we ranked the spillover potential of 887 wildlife viruses. Validating the risk assessment, the top 12 were known zoonotic viruses. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. The color of nectar is often used as a cue for pollinator attraction, but the mechanisms underlying this process are poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We identify three enzymes that are necessary or sufficient for the production of this pigment, and show that the same three enzymatic activities are involved in the production of the red nectar of the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae. Our findings suggest that the red color of nectar is a widespread and convergently evolved trait, and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work provides a better understanding of the mechanisms underlying the evolution of the color of nectar, and may have implications for the study of vertebrate-pollinated plants.

We present a genome-wide analysis of a group of individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who lived mostly between the 5th and 6th centuries AD. We show that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly consistent with that of modern northern and central Europeans, but that the genetic ancestries of women are very heterogeneous, including signals of genetic ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we show that some of the women had skull deformations that were used to shape the faces of the women in the illuminated manuscripts of the time. These results indicate that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. Finally, we show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results suggest that the genetic effects of positive selection may have been already present in the population before the rise of Christianity. This study provides insights into the genetic history of Europe during a period of major cultural change.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of two bat coronaviruses, HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings are important for understanding the origin and evolution of MERS-CoV and for developing strategies to prevent future outbreaks of bat coronaviruses. This study also provides insights into the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV in humans. (Show more)

We describe the use of a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to identify the pathogen landscape of undifferentiated febrile illness in a resource-scarce setting. We show that mNGS can be used to identify a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including the first detection of chikungunya virus in Cambodia. This study demonstrates the feasibility of mNGS for pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings and the potential for rapid public health response. This approach can be used to identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This study provides a blueprint for the use of mNGS for pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings. The human genome is replicated in a process that is highly similar to the process used by the bacterium S. cerevisiae. However, the stability of the complex that is formed by the human DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) and the human proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) sliding clamp is unknown. We developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. The results indicate that human pol δ maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique insight into the mechanism of lagging strand replication in humans. It also provides a unique model for studying the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme in other organisms. This study will be of interest to the general scientific community and to the biomedical community.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enigmatic problems in science. In this paper, we describe the first in vitro evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme, which can replicate RNA and synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules. This work represents a major step toward the creation of a living RNA system in the laboratory.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our work also provides a new method for measuring the physical appearance of neighborhoods, which can be used to study the spatial distribution of urban amenities and the spatial dynamics of urban change. This method can also be used to study the physical appearance of other cities around the world.

The treatment of severe and critical COVID-19 patients is still a challenge. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathway, can improve the clinical outcome immediately. This study provides a new treatment strategy for severe and critical COVID-19 patients.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but at high concentrations it is toxic. The ability to control copper levels is therefore important for the health of the cell. In this study, we show that Aspergillus fumigatus has a natural product biosynthetic gene cluster that binds copper and has antimicrobial properties. This is a significant finding, as it suggests that fungi may have evolved the ability to control copper levels, and that this may be important for the health of the cell.

The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary rock from Gale crater, Mars, is a significant discovery. Tridymite is a high-temperature (>870 °C) mineral, and the detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at a crater floor, with no obvious volcanic or hydrothermal source, is a unique discovery. The tridymite is cogenetic with other crystalline minerals, and the sedimentary rock is a likely source for the tridymite, feldspar, and amorphous silica. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary rock is consistent with the presence of tridymite in basalts on Earth, and the sedimentary rock is a potential source for tridymite in basalts.

The geographic distribution of frost events in the spring is changing as a result of climate warming. We show that the geographic distribution of frost risk is changing in the Northern Hemisphere, and that the resistance strategies of trees are not adapted to the new risk. Our findings have implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are central to the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease, but the mechanisms by which they contribute to disease are not fully understood. We show that Th17 cells can contribute to the development of colitis by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease and that targeting both the Th17 and Th1 cell compartments may be a promising strategy for the treatment of this disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. We report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients, which can be used to study the disease and test potential therapies. This will be a major advance in ALS research and will enable the study of the disease in a living patient, which is currently not possible.

The gut microbiota of ticks is critical for the transmission of pathogens to vertebrate hosts. Here, we show that the tick-borne pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the composition of the gut microbiota and enhances the ability of Anaplasma to infect the tick. We demonstrate that the protein binds to the bacterial cell wall, altering the integrity of the peritrophic matrix and the ability of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide a mechanistic understanding of how a pathogen can influence the composition of the gut microbiota to enhance the ability of the vector to transmit pathogens. This knowledge will be critical for the development of strategies to mitigate the spread of vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. However, the study of the evolution of the avian tail is complicated by the fact that the tail is a complex structure that is difficult to study in fossils. Here, we describe a basal member of the group of birds with a short tail, Jinguofortis, and show that this group of birds had a mosaic evolution of the tail.

We show that the water vapor in the stratosphere is increasing with tropospheric temperature, implying that the water vapor in the stratosphere is also warming the stratosphere. This is a new feedback in climate change, and it is significant.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, which are often used to blend in with their surroundings. In this study, we show that the occurrence of blue-green colors in vertebrates has evolved multiple times, and that the underlying mechanism is the presence of a class of proteins that bind biliverdin, a molecule that is abundant in the blood of vertebrates. We describe these proteins, which we name biliverdin-binding serpins, and show that they are most similar to human antitrypsin, but with a remarkable functional diversification. Our results present molecular and functional evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. This study provides a molecular and functional framework for understanding the evolution of color in vertebrates. It also provides a tool for understanding the function of serpins, which are important in health and disease.

Hypoxia is a feature of many solid tumors, and is associated with the maintenance of the stemness of cancer stem cells. We show that hypoxia induces expression of a m6A demethylase, AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which increases the expression of pluripotency factors, and induces the maintenance of cancer stem cell properties. These findings have implications for the treatment of breast cancer, which is the most common cancer in women, and the most lethal.

The Bible is one of the most widely read books in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, and the source of the parchment used to make them has been a long-standing controversy. We have developed a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but we did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This method could be used to identify the source of parchment used in other historical documents. (PsycINFO Database Record

The end-Permian mass extinction is one of the most severe biotic crises in Earth history. The cause of the extinction is unknown, but the timing of the extinction, the carbon cycle changes, and the timing of ecosystem recovery are all critical to understanding the extinction and its aftermath. We present a precise age model for the extinction and recovery, which will allow a more refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction. This will allow insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion, and establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. This work will also provide a critical time point for evaluating the role of the trigger and kill hypothesis in the extinction of nonavian dinosaurs. (Show more)

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a member of the orphan nuclear receptor superfamily, which is involved in various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. However, the role of RORα in the intestine is still unclear. Here, we report that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. Together, we demonstrate that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to

We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein in complex with the receptor ACE2. We find that the spike protein of the currently circulating virus has a number of mutations that are associated with increased infectivity. We show that these mutations are associated with a more open conformation of the spike protein, which may facilitate binding to the receptor. This work provides a structural basis for the increased infectivity of the currently circulating virus. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate the impact of the pandemic on life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our projections imply that the Black−White life expectancy gap will increase by nearly 40%, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These findings underscore the need for urgent action to address the structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected, and to address the social determinants of health that contribute to the Black and Latino life expectancy gaps.
