The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry, and they are the key to understanding the origin of the chemical world. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and we show that this is consistent with the pressure-induced metallization of the elements. Furthermore, we show that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become electron acceptors. This work is a major advance in the understanding of the chemical properties of atoms and the origin of the chemical world. It is also a major advance in the predictive power of chemical models. We believe that this work will have a major impact on the field of chemistry.

We show that the effects of fire on climate are large and potentially large in the opposite direction to emissions. This is because of the large carbon stored in terrestrial ecosystems, which can be released as fires burn. We show that the effects of fire on climate are most effective under lower emissions scenarios, highlighting the importance of reducing emissions to mitigate climate change.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its symbiotic bacteria through the strategic provision of a single glycan, which is catabolized by the bacteria only at night. This glycan is required for the maintenance of the symbiont population and for the periodic acidification of the symbiotic organ, which increases the availability of oxygen to the bacteria. These results suggest that the provision of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms may be a more general mechanism used by animals to regulate the activities of their associated microbiota. This may be particularly important in the context of the immune response, where the presence of symbionts may be detrimental to the host. Thus, the results presented here may have important implications for the understanding of the evolution of symbiosis and the immune response. (Show more)

We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. We show how to represent documents as sequences of topics, and how to identify the gender bias of topics. Our method is flexible and broadly applicable, and can be extended to other domains. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the arrival of Yersinia pestis in Europe in the 14th century, lasted for four centuries. This study shows that the introduction of the plague bacterium into Europe was not a one-time event, but rather repeated over time. We show that the introduction of the plague bacterium into Europe was not a one-time event, but rather repeated over time. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the plague pandemic and its impact on human history. (Show more)

Asteroids are a common component of the marine ecosystem, but in recent years, they have been the focus of a devastating disease that has led to the mass mortality of populations. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that the virus is transmitted by the starfish itself. This is the first time that a virus has been implicated in the cause of a mass mortality event of this magnitude.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a disease with a poor prognosis, and there is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies. We show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the IL1RAP (IL1R3) receptor, which is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells, have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This approach may be applicable to other cancers as well.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island and found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian ancestry. However, the distribution of these ancestries across the island shows that the admixture happened in a sex-biased and heterogeneous way, suggesting that the settlement of Madagascar happened in several independent waves. In addition, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a new perspective on the human history of Madagascar and the origin of the Malagasy people. It also provides a new tool to study the human history of other islands in the Indian Ocean.

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate gene expression. In some cases, the RNA encodes a small protein that has a function distinct from the RNA. Here we describe a dual-function RNA that encodes a small protein that increases the activity of a metabolic enzyme. The protein increases the activity of the enzyme in the presence of oxygen, but not in the presence of carbon dioxide. The protein also interferes with the ability of the RNA to repress the expression of two metabolic genes.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 variants. (Show more)

Crop experts are the primary source of information on the status of crops in the US. However, their assessments are subjective and qualitative, and have not been used to monitor crop conditions. We show how to convert the original data into a continuous, probabilistic variable that can be used to monitor crop conditions and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. We also discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data. Our results demonstrate the potential of leveraging the network of “people as sensors” to monitor the status of crops at a national scale. This approach can be extended to other crops and countries, and can be used to monitor the status of other natural resources.

Language processing is a complex task that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive modulation of neuronal firing rates. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind information over time. We show that this mechanism can support the binding of linguistic features over time, which is a key step in the construction of meaningful sentences. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains unclear. We present the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. (Show more)

The evolution of the plastid genome is a powerful tool to study the origin and evolution of life. Here, we show that the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle, which is a hallmark of the origin of eukaryotes, is linked to a relaxation of purifying selection on the plastid genome. We demonstrate that the evolutionary rates of the plastid genome are linked to the macrostructural and microstructural changes of the genome, the extent of functional reduction, and the establishment of the parasitic lifestyle. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on the plastid genome in a stepwise manner.

The impact of anthropogenic climate change on the probability of extreme droughts in southwestern South Africa has been evaluated through observations and climate models. However, model adequacy and insufficient horizontal resolution make it difficult to precisely quantify the changing likelihood of extreme droughts, given the small regional scale. Here, we use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in past and future decades. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. read more

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has been a major advance in the field of materials science. However, the conditions under which they are formed are still not fully understood. Here, we report the discovery of a new quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this new quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2, provides a link between the discovery of quasicrystals in nature and the laboratory, and it demonstrates that the conditions for the formation of quasicrystals are not unique to time and place but are also dependent on the history of the material. This discovery has implications for the search for new quasicrystal-forming materials and for the search for extraterrestrial quasicrystals. (Show more)

(Bacterio)chlorophylls are the light-harvesting pigments of photosynthesis. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the so-called “cyclase reaction,” is the most important reaction in the biosynthesis of these pigments. The mechanism of this reaction is unknown. We show that the reaction is catalyzed by three different enzymes in plants, cyanobacteria, and bacteria. These enzymes are related to each other, but they are not identical.

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as EAE. Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1, which is known to be involved in the regulation of neuroinflammation. In this study, we found that ASK1 is involved in the regulation of neuroinflammation in both the early and later stages of EAE. We also found that ASK1 is involved in the generation of a proinflammatory environment in microglia/macrophages, which subsequently activates astrocytes to exacerbate neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study provides a better understanding of the role of ASK1 in the regulation of neuroinflammation and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of neurodegenerative diseases. California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. We show that the probability of drought years has increased in recent decades, and that this increase is attributable to human activities.

Autism is a complex disorder with a genetic basis, and the identification of the causal paths that lead to the core symptoms is challenging. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and may facilitate the identification of the causal paths that lead to the core symptoms. (PsycINFO Database Record

This work offers the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but it also serves to highlight considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, however, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.” (PsycINFO Database Record

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of Ca2+ signaling in the immune system, and is also involved in a variety of other cellular processes. In this study, we identify mutations in the CRAC channel that result in a spectrum of phenotypes, from loss of function to gain of function. These findings expand our understanding of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. This study also provides a framework for the study of the role of the CRAC channel in other physiological and pathological processes. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates throughout the brain is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we use a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease to demonstrate that protein aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons, causing non–cell-autonomous pathology. Finally, we show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for the spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may help to identify potential therapeutic targets. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of bats and demonstrated that this protein, which we named MTX (for immunosuppressant), inhibits the antiviral immune response of the host and facilitates viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats and may help to prevent future zoonotic disease outbreaks. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and thus requires one-carbon units for purine and thymidine synthesis. We have developed a strategy to inhibit the one-carbon unit biosynthetic enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), and show that this strategy is effective in blocking the growth of colon cancer xenografts. We have also identified a set of small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1 and SHMT2, and show that these compounds are effective in inhibiting SHMT enzymatic activity. Finally, we have identified a subset of B-cell cancers that are uniquely sensitive to SHMT inhibition, and show that this sensitivity is rooted in defective glycine import. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of B-cell cancers that can be exploited therapeutically. These findings have implications for the treatment of a variety of cancers, and may lead to the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous motor neuron disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins, including SOD1, TDP-43, and FUS, are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. We show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusions are composed of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable state may be a consequence of the unique cellular environment of the motor neuron, which is characterized by a high level of oxidative stress and a low level of protein synthesis. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable state may be a consequence of the unique cellular environment of the motor neuron, which is characterized by a high level of oxidative stress and a low level of

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The study of the early evolution of angiosperms is hampered by the lack of fossils. The study of Montsechia, a plant from the Cretaceous of Spain, has allowed the study of the origin of the angiosperm family Ceratophyllaceae, which is sister to eudicots. Montsechia is an aquatic plant, similar to Ceratophyllum, and is the earliest known member of this family.

The evolution of viruses is of great interest to the scientific community, as it can shed light on the origin of viruses and the evolution of their genomes. Here we present the first ancient viral genomes, which show that the human pathogen B19V has been associated with humans for a long time. We also show that the evolution of B19V is slower than previously thought. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)
We show that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that this acceleration is consistent with climate change.

Pain is a major public health problem, but the nature of the problem is not well understood. We show that, in America today, pain is less common in the elderly than in midlife, and that this is not explained by differences in occupation or obesity. Instead, it is explained by the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950.

The structure and dynamics of enzyme active sites are key to understanding the mechanism of action of enzymes. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. This integrated approach provides insight into the protonation states of the cofactor, substrate, and catalytic side chains, the location and orientation of crystallographic waters within the active site, and the fate of the leaving group. The chemically detailed, three-dimensional structure from NMR-assisted crystallography is key to understanding why the natural substrate indole reacts, but isostere benzimidazole does not. This work highlights the promise of NMR-assisted crystallography for mechanistic enzymology. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe pneumonia caused by a coronavirus that emerged in 2012. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the high mortality rate of the disease stresses the need for the availability of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, a drug that was developed for the treatment of Ebola virus disease, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for the treatment of MERS, and may also be considered for the treatment of other coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This may be of particular importance in the current context of the ongoing outbreak.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its symbiotic bacteria through the strategic provision of a single glycan, which is catabolized by the bacteria only at night. This glycan is required for the maintenance of the symbiont population and for the periodic acidification of the symbiotic organ, which increases the availability of oxygen to the bacteria. These results suggest that the provision of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms may be a more general mechanism used by animals to regulate the activities of their associated microbiota. This, in turn, may have important consequences for the health of the host and the symbionts. (Show more)

This study shows that the quality of teacher–student relationships can be improved through a simple, scalable intervention. The intervention is based on the idea that teachers can be encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. This mindset is associated with better relationships and lower suspension rates. The intervention is simple to implement and can be delivered online. It is scalable and can be implemented in schools around the world.

DNA alkylation is one of the most common DNA lesions, which can lead to a variety of diseases. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the three O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT lesions can induce distinct transcriptional stalling profiles. Intriguingly, pol II stalling at O2-EtdT and N3-EtdT sites is exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. We also identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop), which is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. This work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. These findings will be useful for the development of new strategies for the treatment of DNA alkylation-induced diseases. This article is

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. We show that sequential proteolysis of the S proteins contributes to MERS-CoV infection, and that the first cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection. These findings suggest that the first cleavages may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

This study provides evidence that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can increase sales of vegetarian meals by 40%. This is a large effect, and it is achieved with a simple change to the catering system. The results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering outlets could be a powerful way to improve population health and protect the environment. This approach could be applied in a wide range of settings, including schools, hospitals, and workplaces. The approach could also be applied to other types of food, such as fish, to improve population health and protect the environment.

The cell surface proteome, the surfaceome, is the interface for engaging the extracellular space in normal and cancer cells. Here we apply quantitative proteomics of N-linked glycoproteins to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in oncogene-expressing breast epithelial cells. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a first step toward understanding the role of the cell surface in the development of cancer.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a rapid understanding of the molecular basis of the disease and the virus. Here, we report the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein that has been proposed to interfere with immune responses. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion. This work provides a foundation for understanding the molecular basis of the disease and the virus, which will be critical for the development of effective treatments and vaccines. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can induce cerebral edema, which is a potentially life-threatening condition. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this process is mediated by the hypoxic release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), which acts on CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) in cortical astrocytes to trigger cAMP/PKA signaling, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε, leading to up-regulation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. This process is dependent on CRFR1+ cortical astrocytes, which are also able to release CRF and express CRFR1 and AQP4. Thus, our findings provide a mechanism for the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia and may have implications for the treatment of this condition. (PsycINFO Database Record

We live in an age of big data. In this context, it is important to be able to assess the strength of associations that are found in the data. This is the problem of selective inference. We describe some recent developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The goal is to provide a framework for understanding the strengths of the associations that are found in data. This is an important problem for the social and behavioral sciences, where the data are often large and the statistical methods are sophisticated. The framework that we develop can be applied to many different problems. We hope that it will be useful to researchers in these fields.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the formation of vascular networks. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce EC development remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can induce the formation of functional vascular ECs (ETVECs) from human fibroblasts. ETV2 is essential for the formation of ETVECs, which exhibit EC characteristics in vitro and form mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in NOD SCID mice. Furthermore, ETVECs significantly improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model using BALB/c-nu mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This approach may be useful for the treatment of ischemic disorders. (Show more)

We report the discovery of a third class of ligand for the RTKs anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk). We show that these ligands are essential for the development of iridophores, a type of photoreceptor that is found in the zebrafish retina and in the skin. This discovery expands the repertoire of ligands for these two RTKs and provides a new paradigm for the function of these receptors.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. In this study, we found that STING is required for β-cell function and insulin secretion. Specifically, STING deficiency in β-cells impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion, which was associated with decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes and loss of nuclear translocation of Pax6. These findings provide a new insight into the role of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and may help to understand the molecular basis of T2D. Moreover, our study also suggests that STING might be a potential target for the treatment of T2D.

Influenza A viruses are responsible for the annual influenza epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. The genome of influenza A viruses is segmented into eight fragments, which is an evolutionary advantage but complicates the packaging of the genome. We identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. Disruption of this interaction decreased the amount of viral RNA in the viral particles, resulting in an eightfold increase in empty viral particles. This interaction is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses, suggesting that genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses is limited. Our results provide insights into the molecular details of the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome. They also suggest that the lack of conservation of this interaction might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that is characterized by the formation of atherosclerotic lesions in the arterial wall. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process that is regulated by a variety of factors. In this study, we found that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by flow disturbance is a critical event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the progression of atherosclerosis. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of flow disturbance in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and may lead to the development of a new strategy for the prevention and treatment of atherosclerosis. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has shaped the landscape of the United States for millennia. However, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen dramatically in recent decades, and climate change has likely played a role in the increase. In this study, we show that humans have vastly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire, and that this expansion is largely driven by human activities. We argue that actions to reduce the expansion of human-caused wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards. Our findings highlight the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the role of humans in the expansion of wildfire and the need for actions to reduce the expansion of human-caused wildfires. (Show more)

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our work also provides a method for measuring the physical changes in neighborhoods that can be used to study the spatial distribution of urban change. This method can be extended to measure the spatial distribution of other types of changes in neighborhoods, such as changes in crime, poverty, and housing quality. This method can also be extended to measure the spatial distribution of changes in other types of urban systems, such as changes in the spatial distribution of economic activity and changes in the spatial distribution of social interactions.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecofriendly pest control method. However, the molecular targets of these repellents in arthropods remain to be further elucidated. Here, we report the identification of a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel as a receptor of plant-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and should help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help the understanding of the arthropod–plant adaptation. (Show more)

We present a mathematical model of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. The model is used to estimate the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We also assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from 5 d to 3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection. In the case of favipiravir, a polymerase inhibitor with activity against ZIKV, we predict a dose of 150 mg/kg given twice a day initiated at the time of infection can reduce the peak median viral load by ∼3 logs and shorten the time to undetectable median viral load by ∼2 d. These results can help guide the development of antiviral treatments and the design of clinical trials. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that is triggered by heat stress and is a major threat to the health of coral reefs. However, the underlying causes of bleaching are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling, which is a result of the increased metabolic energy demand of the coral host. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may help us to predict the fate of coral reefs in a changing climate.

The intestinal epithelium is a barrier that protects the organism from the environment. In this study, we show that the intestinal epithelium is also a regulator of the microbiome. We identify a mechanism by which the microbiome can influence the growth of intestinal tumors. Our results suggest that the microbiome can be used as a therapeutic target to control tumor growth. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. This work provides a new perspective on the role of the microbiome in cancer and may have implications for the treatment of other diseases.

Chemotherapy is an important treatment for breast cancer, but many patients do not respond well to it. We show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that this enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to invade, form spheroids, engraft in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, and survive treatment with paclitaxel. Furthermore, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with a humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. Finally, treatment of PDX-bearing mice with cirmtuzumab and paclitaxel was more effective than treatment with either alone in eradicating breast cancer PDXs. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer.

The timing of the onset of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is one of the most debated aspects of the last deglaciation. Here we show that the onset of deglaciation is linked to a series of volcanic eruptions, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and climate changes similar to those observed today.

Freshwater fisheries are an essential source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people, but their importance is often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which we use to assess the role of inland fisheries in food security, biodiversity conservation, and the sustainability of fishery management. We find that inland fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security highlights the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. At the same time, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. Our data can be used to improve the management of freshwater fisheries and protect the ecosystem services they provide. (Show more)

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of the Mo-based oxide are revealed by hard X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, which is the key to achieve high capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This work is expected to be a milestone in the field of aqueous batteries. The adult mammalian nervous system is incapable of regenerating after injury. In contrast, C. elegans, which has a similar number of neurons, is able to regenerate axons and dendrites after injury. We show that this remarkable difference is due to the fact that C. elegans can regenerate axons and dendrites in a manner that is independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is required for regeneration in mammals. This study provides a unique resource for the discovery of genes involved in the control of neuronal regeneration.

The process of meiosis is essential for the production of genetically diverse gametes, which are necessary for sexual reproduction. In flowering plants, meiosis is initiated by the formation of a double-strand break in the DNA, which is followed by the joining of homologous chromosomes. The precise location of these double-strand breaks is critical for the proper timing of meiosis, and the process is therefore subject to strong evolutionary pressure. We describe the distribution of double-strand break formation in the genome of a flowering plant, and find that the distribution is highly conserved across species. This suggests that the process of double-strand break formation is ancient and conserved in the evolution of the plant kingdom.

The resting state network (RSN) is a small fraction of total brain activity, but it is the basis for the analysis of functional connectivity in the brain. Here, we show that the dominant RSN in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the default mode network, but that this RSN is subordinated in Parkinson’s disease. In addition, we show that the dominant RSN is deactivated during task performance, and that this abnormality is partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. Finally, we show that the dominant RSN is associated with cognitive dysfunction in Parkinson’s disease. These results provide a direct link between the resting organization of the brain and the function of the nervous system.

We describe a 5′ cap structure in yeast that is modified by nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+). This cap is found on transcripts that are not 5′ end-processed, suggesting that it may play a role in the regulation of translation.

We show that epigenetic DNA methylation (DNA-me) alterations at specific loci in whole blood (WB) and blood monocytes (Monos) of people with diabetes are associated with glycemia for several years during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT). These epigenetic alterations are similar to those observed in the long-term follow-up (EDIC Study) and are associated with the degree of glycemia during the DCCT. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy during the DCCT on the progression of microvascular complications in the long-term follow-up.

This study provides a deeper understanding of the role of FSIP1 in the progression of triple-negative breast cancer. The results of this study may aid in the design of therapies for patients with triple-negative breast cancer.

Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disease that affects the brain and the gut. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides a rationale for the use of probiotics in the treatment of alcohol dependence. This approach could be useful in the prevention of relapse and in the management of the disease.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not known, and the role of the genes involved in their production in the overall flavor of the fruit is unclear. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also report the discovery of a flavin-dependent monooxygenase enzyme that catalyzes the production of these compounds. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of tomato flavor and will be a valuable resource for the breeding of improved varieties. (Show more)

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation, and its neurons are organized into distinct cell types that are thought to be involved in different aspects of navigation. However, the anatomical and functional organization of these cell types is still poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in the MEC while mice freely explored an open field. We found that grid cells, which are thought to be involved in the formation of a mental map of the environment, are anatomically organized in distinct layers, while other cell types are mixed. These results suggest that grid cells may be largely segregated from other cell types, and that the formation of a mental map may be a unique property of grid cells. This study provides a detailed view of the organization of the MEC, which will be useful for understanding the function of this important brain structure. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FT, which is known to be a key regulator of flowering in plants, is also able to induce flowering in the parasitic plant Cuscuta australis. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study provides a new perspective on the evolution of flowering and flowering regulation. It also provides a new approach to understand the evolution of parasitic plants. This study may also have implications for the study of flowering in general.

The dopamine system of the brain is critical to movement and motivation. We show that the dopamine-containing neurons of the nigro system, which project to the striatum to form the classic nigrostriatal pathway, receive input from striosomes, which are a relatively new component of the striatum. We also show that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making. Thus, striosomes are likely to be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease.

We show that the speed with which people respond to each other is a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.” This signal is used by people to assess the quality of their connections with others, and by third-party listeners to assess the quality of the connections between two people.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for the generation of the heart rate, and their function is critical for the normal functioning of the heart. However, the mechanisms that govern SAN automaticity are not fully understood. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of SAN automaticity. We show that STIM1 is expressed in SANCs and is required for the maintenance of SAN automaticity. Moreover, we demonstrate that STIM1 regulates SAN automaticity by modulating the activity of the plasma membrane ion channels and the content of Ca2+ in the sarcoplasmic reticulum. These findings reveal a previously unknown mechanism that links the content of Ca2+ in the sarcoplasmic reticulum with the electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to the automaticity of the SAN. Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well understood. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact to promote plant defense against insect herbivores. This study provides a better understanding of the role of Si in plant defense and may have implications for the development of sustainable pest management strategies. (Show more)

The lipidome of macrophages is a complex and dynamic system that is involved in a wide range of physiological and pathological processes. In this study, we show that the activity of a specific enzyme, alkylglycerol monooxygenase, is a key regulator of ether lipid metabolism in macrophages. This enzyme is expressed in macrophages and is important for the metabolism of ether lipids, which are involved in the regulation of inflammation. Our results suggest that modulation of the activity of this enzyme can be used as a tool to control the lipidome of macrophages and, consequently, to control the function of macrophages in health and disease.

Language processing is a complex task that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on changes in the excitability of single neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind information over time. We show that this mechanism can support memory for several seconds, which is comparable to the span of language processing. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical step in the development of plant-based biomaterials and biopharmaceuticals. Here, we report the delivery of siRNAs to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are the key design parameters for the internalization and gene silencing efficiencies. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be of interest to the plant biology and biomaterials communities.

The world’s largest freshwater bodies are threatened by nutrient pollution, which is driven largely by nonpoint sources from surrounding watersheds. However, the role of small tributaries in delivering nutrients to coastal areas has been largely overlooked. We show that the 6 largest tributaries of Lake Michigan account for ∼70% of the daily nutrient loads delivered to the lake. However, the remaining 235 tributaries are responsible for the majority of the nutrient loads that are delivered to the nearshore zone. These small tributaries are also more likely to deliver nutrients in dissolved forms, which are more bioavailable to algae. Our findings highlight the importance of small tributaries in driving coastal nutrient pollution and suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on these areas to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient pollution on valuable nearshore ecosystems. We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the dynamics of complex systems that are biased toward rare events, such as the stock market.

We show that the effects of NMDA-receptor antibodies on the brain can be understood in terms of changes in the dynamics of the underlying neuronal network. This approach offers a way to understand the mechanisms of action of these antibodies, which are currently the only treatment for a group of autoimmune encephalitis. It also offers a way to understand the effects of other drugs that affect neuronal network dynamics. This approach may also be useful in understanding the effects of other forms of brain dysfunction, such as those caused by neurodegenerative diseases.

The history of carbon (C) perturbation events throughout Earth’s history has provided key insights into how the Earth system responds to abrupt warming. Here, we present an integrated proxy (carbon and uranium [U] isotopes and paleo CO2) and multicomponent modeling approach to investigate an abrupt C perturbation and global warming event (∼304 Ma) that occurred during a paleo-glacial state. We report pronounced negative C and U isotopic excursions coincident with a doubling of atmospheric CO2 partial pressure and a biodiversity nadir. The isotopic excursions can be linked to an injection of organic matter–derived C over ∼300 kyr and to near 20% of areal extent of seafloor anoxia. Earth system modeling indicates that widespread anoxic conditions can be linked to enhanced thermocline stratification and increased nutrient fluxes during this global warming within an icehouse. This study provides a new perspective on the history of carbon perturbation events and their potential role in the evolution of life.

We show that the world’s largest palm oil certification scheme, the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil, has had a positive impact on reducing deforestation in Indonesia. However, the scheme has not been able to prevent the conversion of forests to oil palm, and the vast majority of certified areas still contain little residual forest cover. We argue that the RSPO must be able to demonstrate that it is having a positive impact on reducing deforestation in order to be considered a tool for conservation and climate change mitigation.

The exocyst complex is a large protein complex that is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. In this study, we discovered a small molecule that binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

In many vertebrates, sex is determined by a single gene, resulting in two sexes. In species with polygenic sex determination, multiple genes interact to determine sex, allowing for more than two sexes. Here we show that the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii has four possible sex classes, which are produced by the interaction of two alleles at a sex determination locus. We show that the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics produced by polygenic sex determination provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. Our results suggest that the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics may be a general consequence of polygenic sex determination. This modularity may be important for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by the presence of high levels of vitamin A aldehyde adducts (bisretinoids) and reactive oxygen species. We sought to understand the role of iron in the retina, given that iron is a key component of the Fenton chemistry that generates reactive oxygen species. We found that iron, as reflected in transferrin receptor expression, was reduced in albino mice with increased levels of bisretinoids. In addition, we found that iron reduced the oxidative/degradation of the bisretinoid A2E in the presence of light and reduced cell death in cell-based experiments. These findings suggest that iron may be a key factor in the photooxidation and photodegradation of retinal pigments. This work provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of iron in the retina and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for retinal diseases. (PsycINFO Database Record

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is fundamental to understand the functioning of the food web. However, the evolution of predator specialization is often considered a dead end, because of the constraints associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that the evolution of the feeding strategy of a group of predators, the siphonophores, is not a dead end, but rather a case of morphological evolution that has allowed the diversification of the feeding strategies of this group.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology.

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and thus requires one-carbon units for purine and thymidine synthesis. We have developed a strategy to inhibit the one-carbon unit biosynthetic enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), and show that this strategy is effective in blocking the growth of colon cancer xenografts. We have also identified a set of small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1 and SHMT2, and show that these compounds are effective in inhibiting SHMT enzymatic activity. Finally, we have identified a subset of B-cell cancers that are uniquely sensitive to SHMT inhibition, and show that this sensitivity is rooted in defective glycine import. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of B-cell cancers that can be exploited therapeutically. These findings have implications for the treatment of a variety of cancers, and may lead to the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics.

This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact can be mitigated by having access to natural landscapes such as forests. This study has important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

Modern farm machinery is the key to the success of modern agriculture, but it has come at a cost of soil compaction. We show that the increase in mechanization has led to the propagation of subsoil compaction into deeper soil layers, with the risk of soil ecological dysfunction now affecting 20% of arable land. This is a global problem that calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery, considering intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This study highlights the importance of considering the ecological history of the landscape when assessing the impact of modern agricultural practices. (Show more)
